channel.title: Yanir Seroussi | Data & AI for Nature
channel.description: Recent content on Yanir Seroussi | Data & AI for Nature
channel.copyright: Text and figures licensed under [CC BY-NC-ND 4.0](https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/) by [Yanir Seroussi](https://yanirseroussi.com/about/), except where noted otherwise

item.title: Psychographic specialisations may work for discipline generalists
item.description: When focusing on a market segment defined by personal beliefs, it’s often fine to position yourself as a generalist in your craft.

item.title: The power of parasocial relationships
item.description: Repeated exposure to media personas creates relationships that help justify premium fees.

item.title: Positioning is a common problem for data scientists
item.description: With the commodification of data scientists, the problem of positioning has become more common: My takeaways from Genevieve Hayes interviewing Jonathan Stark.

item.title: Transfer learning applies to energy market bidding
item.description: An interesting approach to bidding of energy storage assets, showing that training on New York data is transferable to Queensland.

item.title: Supporting volunteer monitoring of marine biodiversity with modern web and data tools
item.description: Summarising the work Uri Seroussi and I did to improve Reef Life Survey’s Reef Species of the World app.

item.title: Our Blue Machine is changing, but we are not helpless
item.description: One of my many highlights from Helen Czerski’s Blue Machine.

item.title: You don't need a proprietary API for static maps
item.description: For many use cases, libraries like cartopy are better than the likes of Mapbox and Google Maps.

item.title: Lessons from reluctant data engineering
item.description: Video and summary of a talk I gave at DataEngBytes Brisbane on what I learned from doing data engineering as part of every data science role I had.

item.title: Artificial intelligence was a marketing term all along â€“ just call it automation
item.description: Replacing ‘artificial intelligence’ with ‘automation’ is a useful trick for cutting through the hype.

item.title: The lines between solo consulting and product building are blurry
item.description: It turns out that problems like finding a niche and defining the ideal clients are key to any solo business.

item.title: Google's Rules of Machine Learning still apply in the age of large language models
item.description: Despite the excitement around large language models, building with machine learning remains an engineering problem with established best practices.

item.title: My rediscovery of quiet writing on the open web
item.description: Reflections on publishing on this website: Writing publicly to share thoughts and documentation beats chasing views and likes.

item.title: The Minimalist Entrepreneur is too prescriptive for me
item.description: While I found the story of Gumroad interesting, The Minimalist Entrepreneur seems to over-generalise from the founder’s experience.

item.title: Revisiting Start Small, Stay Small in 2023 (Chapter 2)
item.description: A summary of the second chapter of Rob Walling’s Start Small, Stay Small, along with my thoughts & reflections.

item.title: Revisiting Start Small, Stay Small in 2023 (Chapter 1)
item.description: A summary of the first chapter of Rob Walling’s Start Small, Stay Small, along with my thoughts & reflections.

item.title: Email notifications on public GitHub commits
item.description: GitHub publishes an Atom feed, which means you can use any RSS reader to follow commits.

item.title: The rule of thirds can probably be ignored
item.description: Turns out that the rule of thirds for composing visuals may not be that important.

item.title: Using YubiKey for SSH access
item.description: Some pointers for setting up SSH access with YubiKey on Ubuntu 22.04.

item.title: Making a TIL section with Hugo and PaperMod
item.description: How I added a Today I Learned section to my Hugo site with the PaperMod theme.

item.title: You can't save time
item.description: Time can be spent doing different activities, but it can’t be stored and saved for later.

item.title: Was data science a failure mode of software engineering?
item.description: Yes, data science projects have suffered from classic software engineering mistakes, but the field is maturing with the rise of new engineering roles.

item.title: How hackable are automated coding assessments?
item.description: Exploring the hackability of speed-based coding tests, using CodeSignal’s Industry Coding Framework as a case study.

item.title: Remaining relevant as a small language model
item.description: Bing Chat recently quipped that humans are small language models. Here are some of my thoughts on how we small language models can remain relevant (for now).

item.title: ChatGPT is transformative AI
item.description: My perspective after a week of using ChatGPT: This is a step change in finding distilled information, and it’s only the beginning.

item.title: Causal Machine Learning is off to a good start, despite some issues
item.description: Reviewing the first three chapters of the book Causal Machine Learning by Robert Osazuwa Ness.

item.title: The mission matters: Moving to climate tech as a data scientist
item.description: Discussing my recent career move into climate tech as a way of doing more to help mitigate dangerous climate change.

item.title: Building useful machine learning tools keeps getting easier: A fish ID case study
item.description: Lessons learned building a fish ID web app with fast.ai and Streamlit, in an attempt to reduce my fear of missing out on the latest deep learning developments.

item.title: Analysis strategies in online A/B experiments: Intention-to-treat, per-protocol, and other lessons from clinical trials
item.description: Epidemiologists analyse clinical trials to estimate the intention-to-treat and per-protocol effects. This post applies their strategies to online experiments.

item.title: Use your human brain to avoid artificial intelligence disasters
item.description: Overview of a talk I gave at a deep learning course, focusing on AI ethics as the need for humans to think on the context and consequences of applying AI.

item.title: Migrating from WordPress.com to Hugo on GitHub + Cloudflare
item.description: My reasons for switching from WordPress.com to Hugo on GitHub + Cloudflare, along with a summary of the solution components and migration process.

item.title: My work with Automattic
item.description: Back-dated meta-post that gathers my posts on Automattic blogs into a summary of the work I’ve done with the company.

item.title: Some highlights from 2020
item.description: Sharing remote teamwork insights, my climate & sustainability activism, Reef Life Survey publications, and progress on Automattic’s Experimentation Platform.

item.title: Many is not enough: Counting simulations to bootstrap the right way
item.description: Going deeper into correct testing of different methods for bootstrap estimation of confidence intervals.

item.title: Software commodities are eating interesting data science work
item.description: Being a data scientist can sometimes feel like a race against software commodities that replace interesting work. What can one do to remain relevant?

item.title: A day in the life of a remote data scientist
item.description: Video of a talk I gave on remote data science work at the Data Science Sydney meetup.

item.title: Bootstrapping the right way?
item.description: Video and summary of a talk I gave at YOW! Data on bootstrap estimation of confidence intervals.

item.title: Hackers beware: Bootstrap sampling may be harmful
item.description: Bootstrap sampling has been promoted as an easy way of modelling uncertainty to hackers without much statistical knowledge. But things aren’t that simple.

item.title: The most practical causal inference book Iâ€™ve read (is still a draft)
item.description: Causal Inference by Miguel HernÃ¡n and Jamie Robins is a must-read for anyone interested in the area.

item.title: Reflections on remote data science work
item.description: Discussing the pluses and minuses of remote work eighteen months after joining Automattic as a data scientist.

item.title: Defining data science in 2018
item.description: Updating my definition of data science to match changes in the field. It is now broader than before, but its ultimate goal is still to support decisions.

item.title: Advice for aspiring data scientists and other FAQs
item.description: Frequently asked questions by visitors to this site, especially around entering the data science field.

item.title: State of Bandcamp Recommender, Late 2017
item.description: Call for BCRecommender maintainers followed by a decision to shut it down, as I don’t have enough time and Bandcamp now offers recommendations.

item.title: My 10-step path to becoming a remote data scientist with Automattic
item.description: I wanted a well-paid data science-y remote job with an established company that offers a good life balance and makes products I care about. I got it eventually.

item.title: Exploring and visualising Reef Life Survey data
item.description: Web tools I built to visualise Reef Life Survey data and assist citizen scientists in underwater visual census work.

item.title: Customer lifetime value and the proliferation of misinformation on the internet
item.description: There’s a lot of misleading content on the estimation of customer lifetime value. Here’s what I learned about doing it well.

item.title: Ask Why! Finding motives, causes, and purpose in data science
item.description: Video and summary of a talk I gave at the Data Science Sydney meetup, about going beyond the what & how of predictive modelling.

item.title: If you donâ€™t pay attention, data can drive you off a cliff
item.description: Seven common mistakes to avoid when working with data, such as ignoring uncertainty and confusing observed and unobserved quantities.

item.title: Is Data Scientist a useless job title?
item.description: It seems like anyone who touches data can call themselves a data scientist, which makes the title useless. The work they do can still be useful, though.

item.title: Making Bayesian A/B testing more accessible
item.description: A web tool I built to interpret A/B test results in a Bayesian way, including prior specification, visualisations, and decision rules.

item.title: Diving deeper into causality: Pearl, Kleinberg, Hill, and untested assumptions
item.description: Discussing the need for untested assumptions and temporality in causal inference. Mostly based on Samantha Kleinberg’s Causality, Probability, and Time.

item.title: The rise of greedy robots
item.description: Is artificial/machine intelligence a future threat? I argue that it’s already here, with greedy robots already dominating our lives.

item.title: Why you should stop worrying about deep learning and deepen your understanding of causality instead
item.description: Causality is often overlooked but is of much higher relevance to most data scientists than deep learning.

item.title: The joys of offline data collection
item.description: Insights on data collection and machine learning from spending a month sailing, diving, and counting fish with Reef Life Survey.

item.title: This holiday season, give me real insights
item.description: Some companies present raw data or information as “insights”. This post surveys some examples, and discusses how they can be turned into real insights.

item.title: The hardest parts of data science
item.description: Defining feasible problems and coming up with reasonable ways of measuring solutions is harder than building accurate models or obtaining clean data.

item.title: Migrating a simple web application from MongoDB to Elasticsearch
item.description: Migrating BCRecommender from MongoDB to Elasticsearch made it possible to offer a richer search experience to users at a similar cost, among other benefits.

item.title: Miscommunicating science: Simplistic models, nutritionism, and the art of storytelling
item.description: Nutritionism is a special case of misinterpretation and miscommunication of scientific results â€“ something many data scientists encounter in their work.

item.title: The wonderful world of recommender systems
item.description: Giving an overview of the field and common paradigms, and debunking five common myths about recommender systems.

item.title: You donâ€™t need a data scientist (yet)
item.description: Hiring data scientists prematurely is wasteful and frustrating. Here are some questions to ask before you hire your first data scientist.

item.title: Goodbye, Parse.com
item.description: Migrating my web apps away from Parse.com due to reliability issues. Self-hosting is a better solution.

item.title: Learning about deep learning through album cover classification
item.description: Progress on my album cover classification project, highlighting lessons that would be useful to others who are getting started with deep learning.

item.title: Deep learning resources
item.description: This page summarises the deep learning resources I’ve consulted in my album cover classification project. Tutorials and blog posts Convolutional Neural Networks for Visual Recognition Stanford course notes: an excellent resource, very up-to-date and useful, despite still being a work in progress DeepLearning.net’s Theano-based tutorials: not as up-to-date as the Stanford course notes, but still a good introduction to some of the theory and general Theano usage Lasagne’s documentation and tutorials: still a bit lacking, but good when you know what you’re looking for lasagne4newbs: Lasagne’s convnet example with richer comments Using convolutional neural nets to detect facial keypoints tutorial: the resource that made me want to use Lasagne Classifying plankton with deep neural networks: an epic post, which I found while looking for Lasagne examples Various Wikipedia pages: a bit disappointing â€“ the above resources are much better Papers Adam: a method for stochastic optimization (Kingma and Ba, 2015): an improvement over SGD with Nesterov momentum, AdaGrad and RMSProp, which I found to be useful in practice Algorithms for Hyper-Parameter Optimization (Bergstra et al.

item.title: Hopping on the deep learning bandwagon
item.description: To become proficient at solving data science problems, you need to get your hands dirty. Here, I used album cover classification to learn about deep learning.

item.title: First steps in data science: author-aware sentiment analysis
item.description: I became a data scientist by doing a PhD, but the same steps can be followed without a formal education program.

item.title: My divestment from fossil fuels
item.description: Recent choices I’ve made to reduce my exposure to fossil fuels, including practical steps that can be taken by Australians and generally applicable lessons.

item.title: My PhD work
item.description: An overview of my PhD in data science / artificial intelligence. Thesis title: Text Mining and Rating Prediction with Topical User Models.

item.title: The long road to a lifestyle business
item.description: Progress since leaving my last full-time job and setting on an independent path that includes data science consulting and work on my own projects.

item.title: Learning to rank for personalised search (Yandex Search Personalisation â€“ Kaggle Competition Summary â€“ Part 2)
item.description: My team’s solution to the Yandex Search Personalisation competition (finished 9th out of 194 teams).

item.title: Is thinking like a search engine possible? (Yandex search personalisation â€“ Kaggle competition summary â€“ part 1)
item.description: Insights on search personalisation and SEO from participating in a Kaggle competition (finished 9th out of 194 teams).

item.title: Automating Parse.com bulk data imports
item.description: A script for importing data into the Parse backend-as-a-service.

item.title: Stochastic Gradient Boosting: Choosing the Best Number of Iterations
item.description: Exploring an approach to choosing the optimal number of iterations in stochastic gradient boosting, following a bug I found in scikit-learn.

item.title: SEO: Mostly about showing up?
item.description: Increasing SEO traffic to BCRecommender by adding content and opening up more pages for crawling. It turns out that thin content is better than no content.

item.title: Fitting noise: Forecasting the sale price of bulldozers (Kaggle competition summary)
item.description: Summary of a Kaggle competition to forecast bulldozer sale price, where I finished 9th out of 476 teams.

item.title: BCRecommender Traction Update
item.description: Update on BCRecommender traction using three channels: blogger outreach, search engine optimisation, and content marketing.

item.title: What is data science?
item.description: Data science has been a hot term in the past few years. Still, there isn’t a single definition of the field. This post discusses my favourite definition.

item.title: Greek Media Monitoring Kaggle competition: My approach
item.description: Summary of my approach to the Greek Media Monitoring Kaggle competition, where I finished 6th out of 120 teams.

item.title: Applying the Traction Bookâ€™s Bullseye framework to BCRecommender
item.description: Ranking 19 channels with the goal of getting traction for BCRecommender.

item.title: Bandcamp recommendation and discovery algorithms
item.description: The recommendation backend for my BCRecommender service for personalised Bandcamp music discovery.

item.title: Building a recommender system on a shoestring budget (or: BCRecommender part 2 â€“ general system layout)
item.description: Iterating on my BCRecommender service with the goal of keeping costs low while providing a valuable music recommendation service.

item.title: Building a Bandcamp recommender system (part 1 â€“ motivation)
item.description: My motivation behind building BCRecommender, a free recommendation & discovery service for Bandcamp music.

item.title: How to (almost) win Kaggle competitions
item.description: Summary of a talk I gave at the Data Science Sydney meetup with ten tips on almost-winning Kaggle competitions.

item.title: Dataâ€™s hierarchy of needs
item.description: Discussing the hierarchy of needs proposed by Jay Kreps. Key takeaway: Data-driven algorithms & insights can only be as good as the underlying data.

item.title: Kaggle competition tips and summaries
item.description: Pointers to all my Kaggle advice posts and competition summaries.

item.title: Kaggle beginner tips
item.description: First post! An email I sent to members of the Data Science Sydney Meetup with tips on how to get started with Kaggle competitions.

item.title: About Me
item.description: About Yanir Seroussi, a full-stack data scientist and software engineer with over a decade of experience.

item.title: Causal inference resources
item.description: This is a list of some causal inference resources, which I update from time to time. You can also check out my posts on causal inference and A/B testing. Books: Causal Inference: What if by Miguel HernÃ¡n and Jamie Robins: The most practical book I’ve read. Highly recommended. Trustworthy Online Controlled Experiments : A Practical Guide to A/B Testing by Ron Kohavi, Diane Tang, and Ya Xu: Building on the authors’ decades of industry experience, this is pretty much the bible of online experiments, which is how causal inference is often done in practice.

item.title: Data & AI Consulting Services
item.description: Yanir Seroussi’s Data & AI consulting services.

item.title: Stay in touch
item.description: Contact me or subscribe to the mailing list.

item.title: Talks
item.description: Just a list of some talks I’ve given, saved here for future reference and for general public benefit. Lessons from reluctant data engineering (presented at DataEngBytes Brisbane 2023; see video and post) Data ethics â€“ beyond curve fitting (given as part of a local fast.ai course in June 2021; see video and post) Moving Automattic to net zero carbon emissions (PublishPress interview from November 2020) Running remote data teams (Data Futurology webinar from June 2020) Bootstrapping the right way (presented at YOW!
